docs.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging the risks of their failure to settle on a recession-fighting package, leaders of the two parties in Congress said today that they would take up the issue again next month when they return from their holiday recess. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said he would like President Bush to call Congress back into session on Jan. 2, three weeks earlier than scheduled, to deal with the economic recovery plan. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, said he, too, was willing to get right back to work on the issue.

headline.main: Both Parties Deflect Blame For Stalemate On Economy

docs.abstract: Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress say they do not want to take up recession-fighting package next month, after they return from holiday recess, and exchange accusations about which side was responsible for failure to pass stimulus package (M)
docs.snippet: Acknowledging the risks of their failure to settle on a recession-fighting package, leaders of the two parties in Congress said today that they would take up the issue again next month when they return from their holiday recess.    Speaker J. Dennis...

docs.lead_paragraph: Complications for an Ally TERROR LIST -- President Bush froze the assets of a Pakistani-based terrorist group that he blamed for the attack on the Indian Parliament last week. Mr. Bush portrayed his action as one intended to support both India and Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, his key ally in the war in Afghanistan, but the reality was far more complicated. A1 U.S.-PAKISTANI RELATIONS -- By adding two more Pakistan-based groups to Washington's terrorism list, President Bush sharply increased the political pressures that have gripped General Musharraf since the Sept. 11 attacks, particularly in dealing with militant Islamic groups in Pakistan and groups fighting Indian forces in the disputed territory of Kashmir. B3

docs.lead_paragraph: Nine months after the official beginning of the recession, the inability of Congress and the White House to agree on a stimulus package no longer has economists as worried that the economy will stumble without additional tax cuts or spending. ''It's strange to be talking about stimulus at this point, because it's so late,'' said Edmund Phelps, an economist at Columbia University. ''There are signs now that gross domestic product is about to turn around.''

headline.main: More Muted Talk About Help for Economy

docs.abstract: Economists disagree on importance, propriety and potential effects of any economic stimulus legislation Congress might enact; some fear that it would prompt Federal Reserve to raise interest rates; others lower forecasts for economic growth because lawmakers have failed to pass any stimulus legislation thus far; other bills stuck in Congress could be of equal importance to business (M)
docs.snippet: Nine months after the official beginning of the recession, the inability of Congress and the White House to agree on a stimulus package no longer has economists as worried that the economy will stumble without additional tax cuts or spending.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a disappointing conclusion to its 2001 session, Congress has adjourned in a blaze of partisan recrimination over the failure to pass a measure to stimulate the economy. Though President Bush and Republican leaders made some last-minute concessions on the bill, their final offer was too costly, too unlikely to help the economy and too unfairly weighted toward corporations and rich taxpayers to be acceptable. On a separate issue, Congress passed a spending bill to provide significant help for Lower Manhattan. But in a last-minute setback that was discouraging, a bipartisan agreement to provide tax incentives to help rebuild the area was blocked by two Republican senators. In the closing hours of work yesterday, Mr. Bush accused the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, of blocking the stimulus bill by using a parliamentary rule that required 60 votes for passage. But it was Mr. Bush who failed to reach across the aisle and negotiate a bill that could be acceptable to more than three conservative Democratic senators. Genuine bipartisanship means working with the Democratic leadership and caucus as a whole, not trying to lure a few members with individual deals.
docs.abstract: Editorial says economic stimulus bill that failed to be passed was too costly, too unlikely to help economy and too unfairly weighted toward corporations and rich taxpayers to be acceptable; says Pres Bush failed to reach across aisle and negotiate bill that could be acceptable to more than three conservative Democratic senators; says genuine bipartisanship means working with Democratic leadership and caucus as whole, not trying to lure few members with individual deals; says it is unfortunate that separate bill pushed by Sens Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York to provide $5 billion in tax benefits for Lower Manhattan businesses got derailed in process
docs.snippet: In a disappointing conclusion to its 2001 session, Congress has adjourned in a blaze of partisan recrimination over the failure to pass a measure to stimulate the economy. Though President Bush and Republican leaders made some last-minute concessions...

docs.lead_paragraph: The LTV Corporation reached a tentative agreement with its workers today to extend unemployment and insurance benefits for displaced workers through February. The agreement was worked out during a United States Bankruptcy Court hearing that had been convened to consider the company's request to void its union contract. Voiding the contract would have eliminated health care and unemployment benefits for up to 100,000 workers and family members.
docs.abstract: LTV Corp reaches tentative agreement to extend unemployment and insurance benefits for displaced workers through February; agreement is worked out during United States Bankruptcy Court hearing that had been convened to consider company's request to void its union contract (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress gave up hope today of reaching a deal this year to help the growing ranks of the unemployed and hasten a recovery from the recession and along with the Bush administration turned instead to partisan finger-pointing over who was to blame for the impasse. Stopped by reporters tonight as he left the Capitol, a bag of Christmas wrapping paper in his hand, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, was asked whether the economic stimulus package was dead. ''Yeah,'' he replied as he went out the door.

headline.main: CONGRESS GIVES UP ON DEAL THIS YEAR TO HELP ECONOMY

docs.abstract: Congress gives up on deal to help economy and turns to partisan finger-pointing over who is to blame for impasse; issue may be tackled again when Congress reconvenes next month, but failure for now of two parties and Pres Bush to agree on legislative package to address first recession in decade leads some economists to mark down their expectations for comeback next year in business activity and job creation; it also suggests that Democrats and Republicans in Congress will head into 2002 election year more divided than ever over taxes, health care and other issues; Bush, Republican-controlled House and Democratic-controlled Senate are not far apart on most issues, but talks fail because they could not agree on how to provide health insurance benefits to people who lose their jobs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congress gave up hope today of reaching a deal this year to help the growing ranks of the unemployed and hasten a recovery from the recession and along with the Bush administration turned instead to partisan finger-pointing over who was to blame for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sandy Weill knows value when he sees it. And now he seems to think that the big run in property and casualty insurance stocks is nearing an end. That is one way to view the announcement yesterday by Citigroup that it plans to sell a 20 percent stake in its Travelers Property Casualty unit to the public next year and then to spin off the rest to its shareholders. [Page 9.]

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Citigroup Goes to the Well Again on Travelers Unit

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris assesses Citigroup's announcement that it plans to sell 20 percent stake in its Travelers Property Casualty unit to public next year and then spin off rest to its shareholders; notes that this is not first time that Sanford Weill, chief exec of Citigroup, has traded this stock, and he must be given credit for excellent timing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first of several farewell appearances yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani listed many of the benchmarks of his administration, like crime reduction, in what seemed an attempt to cement his legacy beyond his much-heralded leadership since Sept. 11. In addressing hundreds of civic and business leaders at the Regent Hotel on Wall Street, Mr. Giuliani reminded his audience that the city had improved tremendously in myriad ways since he took office eight years ago, and he suggested that many of his policies would survive the current damage, both psychic and financial, of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: His Term Ending, Giuliani Celebrates His Record

docs.abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani, in first of several farewell appearances, lists many of benchmarks of his administration, like crime reduction, in what seems to be attempt to cement his leagacy beyond his much-heralded leadership since Sept 11, address to civic and business leaders, Regent Hotel, Wall Street; Giuliani also attends his last town hall meeting, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 Argentine Leader Declares State of Siege Amid Looting President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across the country. The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas in several cities, and four people were killed. The disturbances appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by unemployed workers and organized protests by government opponents. A3 New Terms for Colombia Aid The House attached a series of conditions to aid to Colombia, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, is expected to concur. A19

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after creating the world's largest financial services company by bringing together huge insurance, banking and brokerage businesses, Sanford I. Weill, the chief executive of Citigroup, said yesterday that he was jettisoning most of Travelers Insurance. For Mr. Weill, who took control of Travelers in 1993 and made it his flagship company, the planned split represents a sharp reversal and a rare admission that one of his many acquisitions had not worked out.

headline.main: Citigroup to Shed Part of Travelers Unit in Stock Sale

docs.abstract: Citigroup chief exec Sanford I Weill, nearly four years after creating world's largest financial services company by bringing together huge insurance, banking and brokerage businesses, says that he is jettisoning most of Travelers Insurance; for Weill, who took control of Travelers in 1993 and made it his flagship company, planned split represents sharp reversal and rare admission that one of his many acquisitions have not worked out; Weill plans to sell 20 percent of commercial, auto and home insurance business, known as Travelers Property Casualty Corp, through stock offering early next year that analysts expect to raise $4 billion to $6 billion; Weill photo (M)
